{{distinguish|Discrimination against intersex people}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} {{Transgender sidebar}} [[Discrimination]] or prejudice against [[non-binary]] people, people who do not identify as exclusively masculine or feminine, is a form of [[sexism]]<ref name="Levesque2011">{{cite book | author = Roger J.R. Levesque | title = Encyclopedia of Adolescence | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VdPGF1tfDJsC&pg=PA2641 | accessdate = 20 September 2012 | date = 5 September 2011 | publisher = Springer | isbn = 978-1-4419-1694-5 | page = 2641}}</ref><ref name="LeongPickren2011">{{cite book | author1 = Frederick T.L. Leong | author2 = Wade E. Pickren | author3 = Mark M. Leach |author4=Anthony J. Marsella | title = Internationalizing the Psychology Curriculum in the United States | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RrATt7OYuP0C&pg=PA163 | accessdate = 20 September 2012 | date = 1 November 2011 | publisher = Springer | isbn = 978-1-4614-0072-1 | page = 163}}</ref>, as well as a specific type of [[transphobia]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Norton|first=Jody|title="Brain Says You're a Girl, But I Think You're a Sissy Boy": Cultural Origins of Transphobia|journal=International Journal of Sexuality and Gender Studies|year=1997|volume=2, Number 2|pages=139–164|doi=10.1023/A:1026320611878|issue=2}}</ref> Both [[cisgender]] and binary [[transgender]] people (men and women), including members of [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and transgender ([[LGBT]]) communities, can display such prejudice.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/kelsie-brynn-jones/when-being-trans-is-not-t_b_6340728.html | title=When Being Trans Is Not Trans Enough | work=Huffington Post | date=February 2, 2016 | accessdate=June 4, 2016 | author=Kelsie Brynn Jones}}</ref>
==Social discrimination==
In the [[binary gender]] system, genderqueerness is unintelligible and abjected.<ref name="ftmborderlands">Hale, J.C. (1998) "...[O]ur embodiments and our subjectivities are abjected from social ontology: we cannot fit ourselves into extant categories without denying, eliding, erasing, or otherwise abjecting personally significant aspects of ourselves ... When we choose to live with and in our dislocatedness, fractured from social ontology, we choose to forgo intelligibility: lost in language and in social life, we become virtually unintelligible, even to ourselves..." from ''Consuming the Living, Dis(Re)Membering the Dead in the Butch/FtM Borderlands'' in the ''Gay and Lesbian Quarterly'' 4:311, 336 (1998). Retrieved on 2007-04-07.</ref> A 2008 study in the ''National Transgender Discrimination Survey'' showed that genderqueer and other non-binary individuals were more likely to suffer physical assaults (32% vs. 25%), experience police brutality and harassment (31% vs. 21%), and opt out of medical treatment due to discrimination (36% vs. 27%) compared to transgender individuals who identified within the gender binary (i.e., [[trans man|trans men]] and [[trans woman|trans women]]). This study also found that they were more likely to be [[people of color]] (30% vs. 23%) and younger (under 45) than binary transgender people (89% vs. 68%).<ref name="Harrison2011">{{cite journal |author1=Jack Harrison |author2=Jaime Grant |author3=Jody L. Herman | title = A Gender Not Listed Here: Genderqueers, Gender Rebels, and Otherwise in the National Transgender Discrimination Survey | publisher = Harvard Kennedy School | journal = LGBTQ Policy Journal | volume = 2 | issue = | page = | year = 2011–2012 | doi = | url = http://www.thetaskforce.org/downloads/release_materials/agendernotlistedhere.pdf | format = PDF}}</ref>{{rp|22}} In another study conducted by the [[National LGBTQ Task Force]],<ref name="Harrison2011"/> responders who identified as neither male nor female were less likely to be white and more likely to be multi racial, Black, or Asian, but less likely to be [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latin-American/Spanish in origin]] compared to those who identified as male or female. 20% of non-binary individuals lived in the lowest household income category.<ref name="taskforce">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/gender-listed-genderqueers-gender-rebels-otherwise-national-transgender-discrimination-survey/|title=A Gender Not Listed Here: Genderqueers, Gender Rebels, and OtherWise in the National Transgender Discrimination Survey - The Task Force|website=The Task Force|language=en-US|accessdate=2015-10-21}}</ref>
[[Discrimination|Social discrimination]] in the context of discrimination against non-binary and gender non-conforming people includes the excusing of hate-motivated violence and two, hate-motivated violence itself. Roffee and Waling discovered multiple boundaries when conducting a study into hate speech and violence against LGBTI people, due to the confronting nature of the interviews, which had the potential to distress the participants. Further than this, there is a potential that people would not have elected to participate for fear of being distressed. Once completing the study, Roffee and Waling (2016) discovered that many of the participants' accounts of victimisation could have warranted police involvement, though the participants had refrained from this for personal reasons.<ref>{{cite journal|title=James Roffee & Andrea Waling Rethinking microaggressions and anti-social behaviour against LGBTIQ+ Youth | doi=10.1108/SC-02-2016-0004 | volume=15 | journal=Safer Communities | pages=190–201}}</ref>
== Workplace discrimination ==
=== United States === Unemployment rates for transgender people are approximately twice as high as those for cisgender people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_full.pdf|title=Injustice At Every Turn: A Report Of The National Transgender Discrimination Survey|last=Grant, Jaime M., Mottet, Lisa A., & Tanis, Justin|first=|date=April 26, 2017|website=thetaskforce.org|archive-url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_full.pdf|archive-date=April 26, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=April 26, 2017}}</ref> In the National Transgender Discrimination Survey<ref name="ncte-ntds">{{cite web|title=National Transgender Discrimination Survey|url=http://www.transequality.org/issues/national-transgender-discrimination-survey|website=National Center for Transgender Equality|accessdate=April 26, 2017}}</ref> conducted by the LGBTQ+ Task Force, it was found that almost all non-binary persons had experienced discrimination in the workplace. Their findings show that being out as a non-binary person negatively affects that person's employment outcomes. Though non-binary persons have higher unemployment rates than those who identify with a specified gender, masculine non-binary persons who still appear male, or are not "passing as female" generally have a harder time in the work environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1331&context=masters_theses_2|title=Gender Inequality: Nonbinary Transgender People in the Workplace|last=Davidson|first=Skylar|date=April 26, 2017|website=umass.edu|archive-url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1331&context=masters_theses_2|archive-date=April 26, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
19% of non-binary trans persons reported job loss due to anti-transgender bias, and 90% reported experiencing anti-transgender bias on the job. 78% of those who had transitioned during their time at the workplace were happy with their choice to do so, and reported feeling more comfortable at work, although they experienced more discrimination.<ref name="transgenderlawcenter"/>{{rp|11}}
==Health discrimination==
===United States===
In the 2008 National Transgender Discrimination survey, it was discovered that 14% of gender-nonconforming individuals reported discrimination in medical care, though 36% were "more likely to avoid care altogether when sick or injured because of the fear of discrimination".<ref name="taskforce" /> 43% were likely to have attempted suicide compared to the U.S. rate of 1.6%.<ref name="taskforce" /> A survey conducted among Rural U.S. LGBT populations, suggested that transgender & non-binary patients were three times more likely to find health care providers that have other LGBT patients. They were also three times more likely to drive over an hour out of the way to visit their health care provider due “to the fact that in the last year, one in ten had visited an LGBT-specific health care clinic, which are often located in urban areas.” <ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Whitehead|first=J.|last2=Shaver|first2=John|last3=Stephenson|first3=Rob|date=2016-01-05|title=Outness, Stigma, and Primary Health Care Utilization among Rural LGBT Populations|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0146139|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=11|issue=1|pages=e0146139|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0146139|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4701471|pmid=26731405}}</ref> Transgender & non-binary peoples generally seek greater care because of the stigma and the lack of knowledge about their experience on the behalf of rural physicians.<ref name=":1" />
===United Kingdom===
In a similar survey conducted by UK Trans Info, the vast majority of non-binary responders reported "fear of treatment being denied" as the main deterrent for not seeking healthcare. Many reported anxiety over having to deny their identities or "pretend to be someone [they are] not" in order to receive treatment. As a result, 20% reported self-medicating as an alternative to seeking healthcare. In the same survey, it was reported that most non-binary individuals use National Health Services compared to private practices. 46% of the individuals who used NHS presented themselves as binary to receive treatment and 72% did so while using private services.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Experiences of non-binary people accessing healthcare|url = http://uktrans.info/research/45-medical-research/378-experiences-of-non-binary-people-accessing-healthcare|website = UK Trans Info|accessdate = 2015-10-21}}</ref>
===Australia===
Elderly care in Australia alienated non-binary individuals using strictly male or female practices and social activities before recent changes in their healthcare system. In an attempt to create a more equitable experience for LGBT and gender non-conforming elders, the [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]] created "the National LGBTI Ageing and Aged Care Strategy (the Strategy) the first federal strategy in the world focused on older 'LGBTI' populations" in 2012. [[Sex Discrimination Act 1984|The Sex Discrimination Act of 1984]] was also updated in 2013 to include [[sexual orientation]], [[relationship status]], [[gender identity]], and [[intersex]] status. This act banned any 'faith-based discrimination' that may target transgender or non-binary gender peoples in federal care service.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Ansara|first=Y. Gavriel|date=2015-10-01|title=Challenging cisgenderism in the ageing and aged care sector: Meeting the needs of older people of trans and/or non-binary experience|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ajag.12278/abstract|journal=Australasian Journal on Ageing|language=en|volume=34|pages=14–18|doi=10.1111/ajag.12278|issn=1741-6612}}</ref>
==Legal discrimination== {{distinguish|Legal recognition of non-binary gender}}
===United States===
Despite being more likely to achieve higher levels of education when compared to the general public,<ref name="transgenderlawcenter">{{Cite web|title = Non-Binary Identities & the Law {{!}} Transgender Law Center|url = http://transgenderlawcenter.org/archives/10208|website = transgenderlawcenter.org|accessdate = 2015-10-21}}</ref>{{rp|11}} 90% of non-binary individuals face discrimination, often in the form of harassment in the workplace. Nineteen percent of genderqueer individuals report job loss as a result of their identities.<ref name="transgenderlawcenter"/> Anti-discrimination laws that prohibit discrimination specifically against non-binary individuals do not exist.{{cn|date=October 2017}} However, [[Title VII]] and the current proposed version of the federal [[Employment Non-Discrimination Act]] use such terms as "gender identity" and "gender expression", categories under which non-binary individuals fall due to the fact that their gender expression cannot be defined as male or female.<ref name="transgenderlawcenter" />
Twelve states currently have legislation which bars discrimination based on gender identity.<ref>{{Cite web|title = State Laws That Prohibit Discrimination Against Transgender People - National Center for Lesbian Rights|url = http://www.nclrights.org/legal-help-resources/resource/state-laws-that-prohibit-discrimination-against-transgender-people/|website = www.nclrights.org|accessdate = 2015-10-21}}</ref> Despite these efforts, non-binary individuals are subject to higher rates of physical and sexual assault and police harassment than those who identify as men or women, likely due to their gender expression or presentation.<ref name="Harrison2011"/><ref>{{Cite web|title = 10 Myths About Non-Binary People It's Time to Unlearn|url = http://everydayfeminism.com/2014/12/myths-non-binary-people/|website = [[Everyday Feminism]]|accessdate = 2015-10-21|language = en-US}}</ref>
====Identity documents====
According to the Transgender Law Center, 70% of transgender people are not able to update their identity documents and one-third of have been harassed, assaulted or turned away when seeking basic services,<ref name=osf-2017>{{cite web |title=Gender Identity Recognition at the Border and Beyond |last1=Skeen |first1=Lisa |url=https://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/voices/gender-identity-recognition-border-and-beyond |date=April 5, 2017 |website=Open Society Foundations |publisher= |accessdate=October 26, 2017}}</ref> and one third are not able to update their documents post-transition. <ref name=hrc-2017>{{cite web |title=Understanding the Transgender Community |author=<!--staff writers, no byline--> |url=https://www.hrc.org/resources/understanding-the-transgender-community |date= |website=Human Rights Campain |publisher= |accessdate=October 26, 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, the U.S. State Department was sued for denying a passport to Dana Zzyym, who is a veteran and an intersex and non-binary person. Zzyym wrote "intersex" on their passport form instead of male or female, which were the only two available gender fields on the form. Zzyym was denied the passport, which led to LGBTQ advocacy organizations filing a lawsuit against the U.S. State Department on Zzyym's behalf. The advocacy group [[Lambda Legal]] argued for gender-neutral terms and a third option on U.S. passports, arguing that the existing passport fields violated the [[Due Process Clause]] and [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the U.S. Constitution. The State Department argued that adding additional gender fields to the passport form would prevent the agency's efforts to combat identity theft and passport fraud. The Tenth Circuit Court ruled in favor of Zzyym, the first time in U.S. history that the federal government recognized non-binary people.<ref>https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/intersex-dana-zzyym-passport-decision/</ref>
California, the District of Columbia, New York City, New York State, Iowa, Vermont, Oregon and Washington State have currently removed the surgical requirement to complete a change on a birth certificate. In these states, to change the gender on a birth certificate, one must fill out a standardized form but legal or medical approvals are not required. In Washington D.C., the applicant fills out the top half of the form and a health or social service professional must fill out the bottom half. A person may face obstacles obtaining a court order in order to make a change to documents in other states. Tennessee is the only state that has a specific statute that forbids altering the gender designation on a birth certificate due to gender surgery, while Idaho and Ohio have the same prohibition, but via court decision rather than by statute; and in Puerto Rico, a U.S. territory, a court ruled that gender markers could not be changed on identity documents under any circumstances.<ref>http://www.lambdalegal.org/know-your-rights/article/trans-identity-document-faq</ref><ref name=lambda-state>{{cite web |title=Changing Birth Certificate Sex Designations: State-By-State Guidelines |author=<!--staff writers, no byline--> |url=https://www.lambdalegal.org/know-your-rights/article/trans-changing-birth-certificate-sex-designations |date=February 3, 2015 |website=Lambda Legal |publisher= |accessdate=October 26, 2017 |quote= }}</ref>
In California, the Gender Recognition Act of 2017 was introduced in the State Senate in Sacramento in January 2017, and signed into law by governor [[Jerry Brown]] on October 19. The law recognizes a third gender option known as "non-binary" which may be used on state-issued documents such as driver's licenses to more accurately reflect a person's gender. Senate bill SB179 was originally drafted by State Senators [[Toni Atkins]] and [[Scott Wiener]]. The law also makes it easier for existing documents to be changed, by removing requirements for sworn statements by physicians and replacing it with a sworn attestation by the person seekng to make the change to their documents. The Executive Director of Equality California commented, "It is up to an individual—not a judge or even a doctor—to define a person's gender identity."<ref name="Gutierrez-2017">{{cite web |title=Bill seeks 3rd gender option on licenses, birth certificates |last1=Gutierrez |first1=Melody |url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Calif-lawmakers-seek-nonbinary-gender-10886782.php |date=January 26, 2017 |website=SFGate |publisher=[[Hearst Communications|Hearst]] |accessdate=October 26, 2017 |quote= }}</ref><ref name="Bowerman-2017">{{cite web |title=Female, male or non-binary: California legally recognizes a third gender on identification documents |last1=Bowerman |first1=Mary |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/10/19/female-male-non-binary-california-legally-recognizes-third-gender-identification-documents/779188001/ |date=January 26, 2017 |website=USA Today |publisher=[[Gannett]] |accessdate=October 26, 2017 |quote= }}</ref>
Currently, only two US citizens are believed to be legally registered as non-binary. In [[Oregon]], Jamie Shupe was able to declare their gender as non-binary in June 2016 after a brief legal battle and successfully granted petition for a legal change in gender.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/16/jamie-shupe-first-non-binary-person-oregon|title=Jamie Shupe becomes first legally non-binary person in the US|first=Lauren|last=Dake|date=16 June 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> Following in Shupe's footsteps, [[California]] resident Sarah Kelly Keenan was also able to legally change her gender marker to non-binary in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/californian-becomes-second-us-citizen-granted-non-binary-gender-status-n654611|title=Californian becomes second US citizen granted 'non-binary' gender status|publisher=}}</ref> After both Shupe and Keenan had success with their cases, more people have been inspired to take on the legal battle of changing their gender to a non-binary marker. There are hopes that this will lead to the normalization of non-binary as a legal gender, but there are still no federal laws in place to allow for such a thing.
====Housing====
As of 2017, transgender and [[genderfluid]] students, among others, are given priority when choosing housing at [[The New School]] in New York City.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lifezette.com/polizette/new-york-college-gives-housing-priority-gender-fluid-students/|title=New York College Gives Housing Priority to Gender-Fluid Students|date=2017-04-20|work=LifeZette|access-date=2017-04-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
===United Kingdom===
Non-binary is not recognized as a legal gender in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nonbinary.org/wiki/Legal_gender#UK|title=Legal gender - Nonbinary.org|website=nonbinary.org|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref> The [[Gender Recognition Act 2004]] allowed people to apply to the [https://www.gov.uk/apply-gender-recognition-certificate Gender Recognition Panel] for a change of gender after living as the gender they wished to show on all their legal documents and being given a diagnosis of [[gender dysphoria]] by at least two health professionals. However, this change of gender only allowed for a change from male to female or vice versa.
In 2006 the [[Identity Cards Act 2006]] was introduced, which issued documents to UK residents and linked them back to the National Identity Register database. When the issue of transgender people and their assigned vs. actual gender came up, it was said that transgender people would be issued two cards, each with a separate male and female gender marker.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmpublic/identity/100706/am/100706s01.htm|title=House of Commons Public Bill Committee : Identity Documents Bill|website=www.publications.parliament.uk|access-date=2016-10-10}}</ref> It was also said that eventually the hope for some was that the identity cards would get rid of the gender markers altogether. The [[Identity Documents Act 2010]] made all these cards invalid and called for their immediate destruction.
===Australia===
In 2014, the [[Australian High Court]] legally recognized non-binary as a category for people to identify with on legal documents. After a citizen named Norrie made a request for a third gender identity on legal documents and was eventually denied, Norrie chose to take the matter up with Australia's [[Human Rights Commission]] and their [[Court of Appeal]]. After a four-year long legal battle beginning in 2010, Norrie finally won the case. From this and the legalizing of the matter in [[New South Wales]], the [[Australian Capital Territory]] made the decision to pass a law which recognized non-binary identities. Though this is a step in a positive direction for non-binary identifying Australians, the law currently lacks concise policies on marriage licenses and recognition of partnership for non-binary people. Because of this, Australians registered as non-binary may not be able to legally marry.
In addition to marriage issues, the non-binary marker for Australian citizens requires proof of [[gender confirmation surgery]]. Because non-binary people live outside of the [[gender binary]], they may not wish to obtain gender confirmation surgery. The people not wishing to do so ultimately will not be able to register as non-binary until this portion of the law is amended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xojane.com/issues/recognition-of-nonbinary-gender-in-australian-high-court|title=Australian High Court Legally Recognizes Nonbinary Gender Identities -- But The News Isn't All Good|date=April 8, 2014|author= S.E. Smith|work=xoJane}}</ref>
